body.head: A New Way to Pay Old Debts

div.head: Scene First−A Village−An Alehouse, L. 2 E.
div.stage: Enter Wellborn with a large rough stick, in tattered apparel, from house, L. 2 E.−Tapwell and Froth following.

sp.speaker: Wellborn.
sp.l: No credit, nor no liquor?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Not a suck, sir;
Nor the remainder of a single can
Left by a drunken porter.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Not the dropping of a tap for your morning's draught, sir:
'Tis verity, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: "Verity", you brache! A female dog.(crosses to R.)
The devil turned precisian!Puritan. Rogue, what am I?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Troth, durst I trust you with a looking-glass,
To let you see your trim shape, you would quit me,
And take the name yourself,

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: How, dog!

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Advance your Plymouth cloak,
There dwells, and within call, if it please your worship,
A potent monarch call'd the constable,
That does command a citadel called the stocks;
Such as with great dexterity will hale
Your threadbare, tatter'd−

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Rascal! slave!

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: No rage, sir.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: At his own peril: − do not put yourself
In too much heat, there being no water near
To quench your thirst; and other drink, I take it
You must no more remember; not in a dream, sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Why, thou unthankful villain, dar'st thou talk thus!
Is not thy house, and all thou hast, my gift?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: I find it not in chalk; and Timothy Tapwell
Does keep no other register.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Am not I he
Whose riots fed and clothed thee? wert thou not
Born on my father's land, and proud to be
A drudge in his house?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: What I was, sir, it skills not;
What you are, is apparent: now, for a farewell,
Since you talk of father, in my hope it will torment you,
I'll briefly tell your story. Your dead father,
Old Sir John Wellborn,
My quondam master, was a man of worship;
Bore the whole sway of the shire, kept a great house,
Reliev'd the poor, and so forth; but he dying,
And his estate coming to you,
Late Master Francis, but now forlorn Wellborn −

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Slave, stop! or I shall lose myself.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Very hardly;
You cannot out of your way.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: You were then a lord of acres, the prime gallant,
And I your under-butler.
Oh! you'd a merry time of’t; hawks and hounds,
With choice of running horses; mistresses
And other such extravagances, which
Your uncle, Sir Giles Overreach, observing,
Resolving not to lose the opportunity,
On statutes, mortgages, statutes, and binding bonds,
A while supplied your folly, and, having got
Your land, then left you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Some curate hath penn'd this invective, mongrel,
And you have studied it.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: I've not done yet.
Your land gone, and your credit not worth a token,
You grew the common borrower; no man 'scap'd you;
Where poor Tim Tapwell, with a little stock,
Some forty pounds or so, bought a small cottage;
Humbled myself to marriage with my Froth here,

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Hear me, ungrateful hell-hound! did not I
Make purses for you? then you licked my boots,
And thought your holiday cloak too coarse to clean 'em.
'Twas I that, when I heard thee swear if ever
Thou couldst arrive at forty pounds thou wouldst
Live like an emperor, twas I that gave it
In ready gold. Deny this, wretch!

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: I must, sir;
For, from the tavern to the taphouse, all,
On forfeiture of their licenses, stand bound
Ne'er to remember who their best guests were,
If they grew poor like you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: They're well rewarded
That beggar themselves to make such rascals rich.
Thou viper, thankless viper!
But since you're grown forgetful, I will help
Your memory, and beat you into remembrance;
Not leave one bone unbroken. (beats him)

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Help! Help!

div.stage: Enter Allworth, R.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Hold, for my sake, hold; −
Deny me, Frank? they're not worth your anger.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: For once thou hast redeemed them from this sceptre; (shaking his cudgel)
But let 'em vanish−
Nay, if you grumble, I revoke my pardon.

div.stage: (Wellborn and Allworth talk apart)

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: This comes of your prating, husband.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Patience, Froth; there's law to cure our bruises.

div.stage: Exeunt Tapwell and Froth, into the alehouse, L.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Sent to your mother?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My lady, Frank, my patroness, my all!
She's such a mourner for my father's death,
And, in her love to him, so favours me,
I cannot pay too much observance to her.
There are few such stepdames.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Tis a noble widow,
And keeps her reputation pure, and clear
But 'pr'ythee, tell me, has she no suitors?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: E'en the best of the shire, Frank,
My lord excepted; such as sue and send,
And send and sue again, but to no purpose:
Their frequent visits have not gained her presence.
Yet she's so far from sullenness and pride,
That I dare undertake you shall meet from her
A liberal entertainment.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I doubt it not. Now, Allworth, listen to me,
And mark my counsel: I am bound to give it.
Thy father was my friend; and that affection
I bore to him, in right descends to thee;
I will not have the least affront stick on thee,
If I with any danger can prevent it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I thank your noble care; but, pray you, in what
Do I run the hazard?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Art thou not in love?
Put it not off with wonder.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: In love?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You think you walk in clouds, but are transparent.
I have heard all, and the choice that you have made,
And, with my finger, can point out the north star
By which the loadstone of your folly's guided;
And, to confirm this true, what think you of
Fair Margaret, the only child and heir
Of cormorant Overreach? Dost blush and start,
To hear her only named? blush at your want
Of wit and reason.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Howe'er you have discovered my intents,
You know my aims are lawful; and if ever
The queen of flowers, the boast of spring, the rose,
Sprang from an envious briar, I may infer
There's such disparity in their conditions
Between the goddess of my soul, the daughter,
And the base churl her father.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Grant this true,
As I believe it, canst thou ever hope
To enjoy a quiet bed with her, whose father
Ruined thy state?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: And your's too.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I confess it, Allworth.
Or canst thou think, if self-love blind thee not,
That Sir Giles Overreach, who, to make her great
In swelling titles, without touch of conscience,
Will cut his neighbour's throat, and, I hope, his own too,
Will e'er consent to make her thine? Give o'er,
And think of some course suitable to thy rank,
And prosper in it.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: You have well advised me.
But in the mean time, you, that are so studious
Of my affairs, wholly neglect your own.
Remember yourself, and in what plight you are.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: No matter, no matter. (cross to R.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Yes, 'tis much material:
You know my fortune and my means; yet something
I can spare from myself to help your wants. (offers him money)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: How's this?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Nay, be not angry.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Money from thee ?
From a boy! a stipendiary! one that lives
At the devotion of a stepmother
And the uncertain favour of a lord!
I'll eat my arms first. Howsoe'er blind Fortune
Hath spent the utmost of her malice on me −
Though I am rudely thrust out of an alehouse,
And thus accoutred, − know not where to eat,
Or drink, or sleep, but underneath this canopy −
Although I thank thee, I disdain thy offer:
No−as I, in my madness, broke my state
Without th'assistance of another's brain,
In my right wits I'll piece it; at the worst,
Die thus and be forgotten.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Fare thee well.

div.stage: Exit Allworth, L, Wellborn, R.

div.head: Scene second−A Hall in Lady Allworth's House
div.stage: Enter Amble, Order, Furnace, and Watchall, R.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Set all things right; or, as my name is Order,
And by this staff of office that commands you,
This chain and double ruff, symbols of power,
Whoever misses in his functiön,
For one whole week makes forfeiture of his breakfast,
And privilege in the wine-cellar.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: You are merry, good master Steward.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Let him−I'll be angry.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Why, fellow Furnace, 'tis not twelve o'clock yet,
Nor dinner taking up; then, 'tis allowed,
Cooks, by their places, may be choleric.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: You think you've spoken wisely, goodman Amble,
My lady's go-before. Her usher

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Nay, nay, no wrangling.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Twit me with the authority of the kitchen!
At all hours, and all places, I'll be angry;
And thus provoked, when I am at my prayers
I will be angry.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: There was no hurt meant.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: I'm friends with thee; and yet I will be angry.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: With whom?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: No matter whom: yet, now I think on it,
I'm angry with my lady.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Heaven forbid, man!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: What cause has she given thee?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Cause enough, master Steward.
I was entertain'd by her to please her palate,
And, till she forswore eating, I performed it.
Now, since our master, noble Allworth, died,
Though I crack my brains to find out tempting sauces,
When I am three parts roasted
And the fourth part parboiled, to prepare her viands,
She keeps her chamber, dines with a panada
Or water-gruel, my skill ne'er thought on.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: But your art is seen in the dining-room.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: By whom?
By such as pretend love to her, but come
To feed upon her. Yet, of all the harpies
That do devour her, I am out of charity
With none so much as the thin-gutted squire
That's stolen into commission.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Justice Greedy?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: The same, the same. Meat's cast away upon him;
It never thrives. He holds this paradox;
Who eats not well, can ne'er do justice well:
His stomach's as insatiate as the grave.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: One knocks. Exit Watchall, L..]

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Our late young master!

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Welcome, sir.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: You're welcome,
If you have a stomach, a cold bake-meat's ready.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: His father's picture in little.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: We are all your servants.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: At once, my thanks to all;
This is yet some comfort. Is my lady stirring?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Her presence answers for us.

div.stage: Enter Lady Allworth, Abigail, and Tabitha, R.1 E.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: Sort those silks well. I'll take the air alone.
sp.stage: Exeunt Abigail and Tabitha, R. 1 E.
sp.l: And, as I gave directions, if this morning
I am visited by any, entertain 'em
As heretofore; but say, in my excuse,
I am indispos'd.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: I shall, madam.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: Do, and leave them.
sp.stage: Exeunt Order, Furnace, and Amble, L.
sp.l: Nay, stay you, Allworth.
Tell me, how is it with your noble master?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Ever like himself,
No scruple lessen'd in the full weight of honour.
He did command me (pardon my presumption),
As his unworthy deputy, to kiss
Your ladyship's fair hands.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I'm honour'd in
His favour to me. Does he hold his purpose
For the Low Countries?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Constantly, good madam;
But will in person first present his services.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: And how approve you of his course? you are yet
Like virgin parchment, capable of any
Inscription, vicious or honourable.
I will not force your will, but leave you free
To your own election.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Any form you please,
I will put on; but, might I make my choice,
With humble emulation I would follow
The path my lord marks to me.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: 'Tis well answer'd,
And I commend your spirit. Your father, Allworth,
My ever-honour'd husband, some few hours
Before the will of Heaven took him from me,
Did commend you, e'en by the dearest ties
Of perfect love between us, to my charge;
And, therefore, what I speak, you are bound to hear
With such respect as if he lived in me.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I have found you,
Most honoured madam, more than a mother to me;
And, with my utmost strengths of care and service,
Will labour that you never may repent
Your bounties showered upon me.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I much hope it.
These were your father's words: "If e'er my son
Follow the war, tell him it is a school
Where all the principles tending to honour
Are taught, if truly followed: but for such
As repair thither as a place in which
They do presume they may with license practise
Their lusts and riots, they shall never merit
The noble name of soldiers.
To obey their leaders, and shun mutinies;
To bear with patiënce the winter's cold
And summer's scorching heat
To dare boldly
In a fair cause, and for the country's safety
To run upon the cannon's mouth undaunted;
These are the essential parts make up a soldier,
Not swearing, dice, or drinking."

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: There's no syllable
You speak, but is to me an oracle.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: To conclude:
Beware ill company, for often men
Are like to those with whom they do converse;
And, from one man I warn you, and that's Wellborn:
Not 'cause he's poor−that rather claims your pity;
But that he's in his manners so deprav'd,
And hath to vicious courses lost himself.
'Tis true, your father loved him, while he was
Worthy the loving; but if he had liv'd
To have known him as he is, he had cast him off,
As you must do.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I shall obey in all things.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Follow me to my chamber, you shall have gold
To furnish you like my son, and still supply'd,
As I hear from you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I am still bound to you.

div.stage: Enter Order, Watchall, Sir Giles Overreach, Marrall, Greedy, Furnace, and Amble, L.−Marrall goes behind to R.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Not to be seen!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Still cloister'd up! Her reason,
I hope, assures her, though she make herself
Close prisoner ever for her husband's loss,
'Twill not recover him.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis her will.
Which we, that are her servants, ought to serve,
And not dispute: howe'er, you're nobly welcome;
And, if you please to stay, that you may think so,
There came, not six days since, from Hull, a pipe
Of rich Canary, which shall spend itself
For my lady's honour.

div.stage: (Sir Giles and Marrall converse apart up Stage)

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Is it of the right race?

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Yes, Master Greedy.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: How his mouth runs o'er!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: I'll make it run, and run.
Save your good worship!

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Honest Master Cook, thy hand; again: how I love thee!
Are the good dishes still in being? speak, boy.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: If you've a mind to feed, there is a chine
Of beef, well season'd.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Good.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: A pheasant, larded.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: That I might now give thanks for't!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Besides, there came last night, from the forest of Sherwood,
The fattest stag I ever cook'd.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: A stag, man?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: A stag, sir; part of it prepared for dinner,
And baked in puff-paste.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Puff-paste too! Sir Giles,
A ponderous chine of beef! a pheasant larded!
And red deer too, Sir Giles, and bak'd in puff-paste!
All business set aside, let us give thanks here.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: You know, we cannot.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your worships are to sit on a commission,
And if you fail to come, you lose the cause.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Cause me no causes. I'll prove't, for such dinner,
We may put off a commission: you shall find it
Henrici decimo quarto.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Fie, Master Greedy?
Will you lose me a thousand pounds for a dinner?
No more, for shame! we must forget the belly
When we think of profit. (crosses to Marrall)

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Well, you shall o'er-rule me;
I could e'en cry now. − Do you hear, master Cook,
Send but a corner of that immortal pasty,
And I, in thankfulness, will, by your boy,
Send you − a brace of three-pences.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Will you be so prodigal?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Remember me to your lady.
Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You know me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I did once, but now I will not;
Thou art no blood of mine. (crosses to L.)Avaunt, thou beggar!
If ever thou presume to cross me more,
I'll have thee cag'd and whipp'd.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Think of pye-corner, Furnace! (whispers to Furnace)

div.stage: Exeunt Greedy and Marrall, L. Marrall eyeing Wellborn contemptuously−Wellborn takes a chair and sits down in the centre of the stage.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Will you out, sir?
I wonder how you durst creep in.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: This is rudeness,
And saucy impudence.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Cannot you stay
To be served, among your fellows, from the basket,
sp.note: The broken and spare victuals was formerly collected in a basket, and given to the destitute
sp.l: But you must press into the hall?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Pr'y'thee, vanish
Into some outhouse, though it be the pig-stye;
My scullion shall come to thee.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: This is rare:
Oh, here's Tom Allworth. Tom!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: We must be strangers:
Nor would I have you seen here for a million.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Better and better. He contemns me too!

div.stage: Enter Abigail and Tabitha, R. cross to L.>

sp.speaker: Abigail.
sp.l: Mercy preserve my sight!
What thing is this?

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: Let's hence, for heaven's sake, or I shall swoon.

div.stage: (they cross, L.)

sp.speaker: Abigail.
sp.l: I begin to faint already.

div.stage: Exeunt Abigail and Tabitha, L.

sp.speaker: Furnace.
sp.l: Will you know your wayfra?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Or shall we teach it you,
By the head and shoulders?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: No; I will not stir:
Do you mark? I will not. (starts up) let me see the wretch
That dares attempt to force me. Why, you slaves,
Created only to make legs, and cringe;
To carry in a dish, and shift a trencher;
That have not souls only to hope a blessing
Beyond your master's leaving − who advances?
Who shews me the way? (threatening them)

sp.speaker: All the Servants.
sp.l: Help, fellows, help! Within there!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Here comes my lady.

div.stage: Enter Lady Allworth, R.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: How now? What noise is this?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Madam, my designs
Bear me to you.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: To me?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: And though I've met with
But ragged entertainment from your grooms here,
I hope from you to receive that noble usage
As may become the true friend of your husband,
And then I shall forget these.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I am amazed
To see and hear this rudeness. Dar'st thou think,
Though sworn, that it can ever find belief,
That I, who to the best men of this country
Denied my presence since my husband's death,
Can fall so low, as to exchange words with thee?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Scorn me not, good lady;
But, as in form you are angelical,
Imitate the heavenly natures, and vouchsafe
At the least awhile to hear me. You will grant
The blood that runs in this arm is as noble
As that which fills your veins; your swelling titles,
Your ample fortune, with your men's observance,
And women's flattery, are in you no virtues;
Nor these rags, with my poverty, in me vices.
You have a fair fame, and, I know, deserve it;
Yet, lady, I must say, in nothing more
Than in the pious sorrow you have shewn
For your late noble husband.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: There he touch'd her.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: That husband, madam, was once in his fortune
Almost as low as I; want, debts, and quarrels
Lay heavy on him: let it not be thought
A boast in me, though I say I relieved him.
'Twas I that gave him fashion; mine the sword,
That did on all occasions second his;
I brought him on and off with honour, lady;
And when in all men's judgments he was sunk,
And, in his own hopes, not to be buoyed up,
I stepped unto him, took him by the hand,
And set him upright.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Are not we base rogues,
That could forget this?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I confess you made him
Master of your estate; nor could your friends,
Though he brought no wealth with him, blame you for't;
For he had a shape, and to that shape a mind
Made up of all parts, either great or noble;
So winning a behaviour, not to be
Resisted, madam.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Tis most true, he had.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: For his sake, then, in that I was his friend,
Do not contemn me.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: For what's past excuse me:
I will redeem it. (offers him her purse)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Madam, on no terms:
I will not beg nor borrow sixpence of you;
But be supplied elsewhere, or want thus ever.
Only one suit I make; pray give me leave.
sp.stage: (Lady Allworth signs to the Servants, who retire to the top of stage)
sp.l: I will not tire your patience with relation
Of the bad arts my uncle Overreach
Still forg'd, to strip me of my fair possessions;
Not how he now shuts door upon my want.
And my low hopeless state. Hopeless indeed,
But that in your kind courtesy I spy
A hope to raise it:−would you but vouchsafe
To your dear husband's friend−as well you may,
Your honour still let free−but such feign'd grace,
As might beget opinion in Sir Giles
Of a true passion tow'rds me, you would see,
In the mere thought to prey on me again,
When all that's yours were mine, he'd turn my friend;
And, that no rub might stay my course to you,
Quit all my owings, set me rimly forth,
And furbishg;d well with goild :−which I should use,
I trust, to your no shame, lady; but live
Ever a grateful debtor to your gentleness.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: What! nothing else?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Nothing, unless you please to charge your servants
To throw away a little respect upon me.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: All you demand is yours. (she beckons the Servants, who advance a little, L.)
Respect this gentleman,
As 'twere myself. Adieu, dear Master Wellborn−
Pray let me see you with your oftenest means:
I am ever bound to you. (going, R.)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Your honour's servant. (kisses her hand)

div.stage: Exit Lady Allworth, R.

sp.speaker: All the Servants
sp.stage: (coming up to Wellborn with bows and cringes)
sp.l: Ah, sweet sir−-

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: [To the Servants] Nay, all's forgiven, all forgotten, friends:
And, for a lucky omen to my project,
Shake hands, and end all quarrels in the cellar.

sp.speaker: All the Servants
sp.l: Agreed, agreed. Still merry Master Wellborn.

div.stage: Exeunt all the Servants, L.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Faith, a right worthy and a liberal lady,
Who can at once so kindly meet my purposes,
And brave the flouts of censure, to redeem
Her husband’s friend !—When, by this honest plot
The world believes she means to heal my wants
With her extensive wealth, each noisy creditor
Will be struck mute; and I, thus left at large
To practise on my uncle Overreach,
May work, perhaps, the measure to redeem
My mortgag’d fortune; which he stripp’d me of,
When headlong dissipation quell’d my reason.
The fancy pleases : if the plot succeed,
Tis a New Way to Pay Old Debts, indeed. Exit, L.

div.head: SCENE I. The Skirts of Lady Allworth's Park.
div.stage: Enter Sir Giles and Marrall, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: He's gone, I warrant thee; this commission crush'd him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your worships has the way on'ty and ne'er miss
To squeeze these unthrifts into air: and yet,
The chap-fall'n justice did his part, returning,
For your advantage, the certificate,
Against his conscience, and his knowledge too,
With your good favour, to the utter ruin
Of the poor farmer.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Twas for these good ends
I made him a justice: he that bribes his belly,
Is certain to command his soul.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I wonder why, your worship having
The power to put this thin-gut in commission,
You are not in't yourself?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Thou art a fool;
In being out of office I am out of danger;
Where, if I were a justice, besides the trouble,
I might or out of wilfulness or error
Run myself finely into a praemunire,
And so become a prey to the informer.
No, I'll have none of’t; 'tis enough I keep
Greedy at my devotion: so he serve
My purposes, let him hang or damn, I care not;
Friendship is but a word. (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: You are all wisdom.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I would be worldly-wise; for the other wisdom,
That does prescribe us a well-govern'd life,
And to do right to others as ourselves,
I value not an atom.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: What course take you,
With your good patience, to hedge in the manor
Of your neighbour, Master Frugal? as 'tis said,
He will nor sell, nor borrow, nor exchange;
And his land, lying in the midst of your many lordships,
Is a foul blemish.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I have thought on't, Marrall,
And it shall take. (placing his hand on Marrall's shoulder) I must have all men, sellers,
And I the only purchaser.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Tis most fit, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I'll therefore buy some cottage near his manor,
Which done, I'll make my men break ope his fences,
Ride o'er his standing corn, and in the night
Set fire to his barns, or break his cattle's legs:
These trespasses draw on suits, and suits expences,
Which I can spare, but will soon beggar him.
When I have harried him thus two or three year,
Though he sue in forma pauperis, in spite
Of all his thrift and care, he'll grow behind-hand.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The best I ever heard! I could adore you.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Then, with the favour of my man of law,
I will pretend some title: want will force him
To put it to arbitrement; then, if he sell
For half the value, he shall have ready money,
And I possess his land.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Wellborn was apt to sell, and needed not
These fine arts, sir, to hook him in.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Well thought on.
This varlet, Welborn, lives too long, to upbraid me
With my close cheat put upon him. Will nor cold
Nor hunger kill him?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know not what to think on't.
I have used all means; and the last night I caused
His host, the tapster, turn him out of doors;
And have been since with all your friends and tenants,
And, on the forfeit of your favour, charged them,
Though a crust of mouldy bread would keep him from starving,
Yet they should not relieve him.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: That was something, Marrall, but thou must go further,
And suddenly, Marrall.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Where, and when you please, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I'd have thee seek him out, and, if thou canst,
Persuade him that 'tis better steal than beg;
Then, if I prove he has but robb'd a hen-roost,
Not all the world shall save him from the gallows.
Do anything to work him to despair;
And 'tis thy master-piece.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll do my best, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I am now on my main work, with the Lord Lovell,
The gallant-minded, popular Lord Lovell,
The minion of the people's love. I hear
He's come into the country, and my aims are
To insinuate myself into his knowledge,
And then invite him to my house.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I have you;
This points at my young mistress.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: She must part with
That humble title, and be honourable,
Right honourable, Marrall, my right honourable daughter,
If all I have, or e'er shall get, will do it.
I'll have her well-attended; there are ladies
Of errant knights decay'd and brought so low,
That, for cast clothes and meat will gladly serve her.
And 'tis my glory, though I come from the city,
To have their issue, whom I have undone,
To kneel to mine as bond-slaves.

sp.speaker: Mar. '
sp.l: 'Tis fit state, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: And therefore, I'll not have a chambermaid
That ties her shoes, or any meaner office,
But such whose fathers were right worshipful.
'Tis a rich man's pride! there having ever been
More than a feud, a strange antipathy,
Between us and true gentry. (crosses, L.)

div.stage: Enter Wellborn, R.>

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: See, who's here, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Hence, monster! prodigy!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Call me what you will;−
I am your nephew, sir, your sister's son.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Avoid my sight! thy breath's infectious, rogue!
I shun thee as a leprosy, or the plague.
Come hither, Marrall – aside this is the time to work him.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I warrant you, sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: By this light I think he's mad.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Mad! had you ta'en compassion on yourself,
You long since had been mad.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You've ta'en a course,
Between you and my venerable uncle,
To make me so.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The more pale-spirited you,
That would not be instructed. I swear deeply −

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: By what?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: By my religion.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Thy religion!
The devil's creed: − but what would you have done?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Had there been but one tree in the whole shire,
Or any hope to compass a single halter,
Before, like you, I had outliv'd my fortunes,
A withe had served my turn to hang myself.
I am zealous in your cause; pray hang yourself
And presently, as you love your credit.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I thank you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you stay till you die in a ditch? −
Or, if you dare not do the feat yourself,
But that you'll put the state to charge and trouble,
Is there no purse to be cut, house to be broken,
Or market-woman with eggs, that you may murder,
And so dispatch the business?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Here's variety,
I must confess; but I'll accept of none
Of all your gentle offers, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: If you like not hanging, drown yourself! take some course
For your reputation.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Twill not do, dear tempter,
With all the rhetoric the fiend hath taught you.
I am as far as thou art from despair;
Nay, I have confidence, which is more than hope,
To live, and suddenly, better than ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ha! ha! these castles you build in the air
Will not persuade me or to give or lend
A token to you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I'll be more kind to thee:
Come, thou shalt dine with me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With you!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Nay more, dine gratis.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Under what hedge, I pray you? or at whose cost?
Are they padders or gipsies, that are your consorts?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Thou art incredulous; but thou shalt dine
Not alone at her house, but with a gallant lady;
With me, and with a lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Lady! what lady?
With the lady of the lake, or queen of fairies?
For, I know, it must be an enchanted dinner.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: With the Lady Allworth, knave.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Nay, now there's hope
Thy brain is cracked.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Mark there, with what respect
I am entertained.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With choice, no doubt, of dog-whips.
Why, dost thou ever hope to pass her porter?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Tis not far off, go with me; trust thine own eyes.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Troth, in my hope, or my assurance rather,
To see thee curvet, and mount like a dog in a blanket,
If ever thou presume to pass her threshold,
I will endure thy company.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Come along then.

div.stage: Exeunt, R.

div.head: SCENE SECOND.−The Hall in Lady Allworth's House
div.stage: Enter Watchall, Furnace, Order, Amble, and Allworth, R.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Your courtesies overwhelm me: I much grieve
To part from such true friends, and yet find comfort,
My attendance on my honourable lord,
Whose resolution holds to visit my lady,
Will speedily bring me back.

div.stage: Knocking without, L. Exit Watchall,L.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: (without, L.) Dar'st thou venture further?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: (ditto)Yes, yes, and knock again.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: (C.)'Tis he; disperse!

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: (R.C.)Perform it bravely.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: (L.C.)I know my cue, ne'er doubt me.

div.stage: Exeunt Furnace, L.U.E Order and Amble, R.
Enter Watchall, Wellborn and Marrall.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: Beast that I was, to make you stay! most welcome;
You were long since expected.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Say so much
To my friend, I pray you.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: For your sake, I so, sir.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: For his sake!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Mum; this is nothing.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: More than ever
I'd have believed, though I had found it in my primer.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: When I have given you reasons for my late harshness,
You'll pardon and excuse me; for, believe me,
Though now I part abruptly, in my service
I will deserve it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Service! with a vengeance!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I'm satisfied: farewell, Tom. (shaking hands)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: All joy stay with you!

div.stage: Enter Amble, R.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: You're happily encounter'd; I ne'er yet
Presented one so welcome as I know
You will be to my lady.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: This is some vision,
Or, sure, these men are mad, to worship a dunghill;
It cannot be a truth.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Be still a pagan,
An unbelieving infidel; be so, miscreant,
And meditate on blankets, and on dog-whips!

div.stage: Enter Furnace, L.U.E.−comes between Wellborn and Marrall, L.C.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: I am glad you are come: until I know your pleasure
I knew not how to serve up my lady's dinner.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: His pleasure! is it possible?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: What's thy will?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Marry, sir, I have some grouse, and turkey chicken,
Some rails and quails, and my lady willed me ask you,
What kind of sauces best affect your palate,
That I may use my utmost skill to please it.

div.stage: (Wellborn whispers Furnace up the Stage)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: (amazed) The devil's enter'd this cook: sauce for his palate,
That, on my knowledge, for almost this twelvemonth,
Durst wish but cheese-parings and brown bread on Sundays!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: That way I like them best.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: It shall be done, sir. Exit Furnace, L.U.E.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: What think you of the hedge we shall dine under?
Shall we feed gratis?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know not what to think;
Pray you make me not mad.

div.stage: Enter Order, R.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: This place becomes you not;
Pray you walk, sir, to the dining room.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I am well here,
'Till her ladyship quits her chamber.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: (aside)Well here, say you?
'Tis a rare change! but yesterday you thought
Yourself well in a barn, wrapped up in pease-straw.

div.stage: Enter Tabitha and Abigail, R.

sp.speaker: Tabitha.
sp.l: O! you're much wished for, sir.

sp.speaker: Abigail
sp.l: Last night,my lady
Dreamt of you; and her first command this morning,
Was to have notice, sir, of your arrival.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: See, my lady.

div.stage: Enter Lady Allworth, R.−Order bows and exit, C.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I come to meet you, and languish'd till I saw you−
This first kiss is for form; I allow a second
To such a friend.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: (aside)To such a friend! heaven bless me!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I am wholly yours; yet, madam, if you please
To grace this gentleman with a salute − (puts Marrall over to Lady Allworth, C.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Salute me at his bidding!

div.stage: (Marrall retreats towards the door, L.)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I shall receive it as a most high favour.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Your friends are ever welcome to me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Run backward from a lady! and such a lady!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To kiss her foot is, to poor me, a favour
I am unworthy of. kneels and offers to kiss her foot

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Nay, pray you, rise;
And since you are so humble, I'll exalt you:
You shall dine with me to-day, at mine own table.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Your ladyship's table! I am not good enough
To sit at your steward's board.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: You are too modest:
I will not be denied.

div.stage: Enter Order, C.−throws the doors wide open.

sp.speaker: Order.
sp.l: Dinner is ready for your ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Come, Master Wellborn: −(to Marrall who is retreating again)
Nay, keep us company.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I was ne'er so graced.

div.stage: Lady Allworth and Wellborn take Marrall by the hand−he bowing with the greatest servility−they retire through C.D. followed by Abigail, Tabitha, and Amble−the doors are closed.
Enter Furnace, L.U.E.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: So! we've play'd our parts, and are come off well;
But if I know the mystery, why my lady
Consented to it, may I perish!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Would I had
The roasting of his heart that cheated him,
And forces the poor gentleman to these shifts!
By fire! for cooks are Persians, and swear by it,
Of all the griping and extorting tyrants
I ever heard or read of, I ne'er met
A match to Sir Giles Overreach.

sp.speaker: Watch.
sp.l: What will you take
To tell him so, fellow Furnace?

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Just as much
As my throat is worth, for that would be the price on't.
To have a usurer that starves himself,
To grow rich, and then purchase, is too common:
But this Sir Giles feeds high; keeps many servants;
Rich in his habit, vast in his expenses;
Yet he, to admiration, still increases
In wealth and lordships.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: He frights men out of their estates,
And breaks through all law-nets, made to curb ill men,
As they were cobwebs. No man dares reprove him.
Such a spirit to dare, and power to do, were never
Lodg'd so unluckily.

div.stage: Enter Amble, C.D.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Ha! ha! I shall burst.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Contain thyself, man.

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Or make us partakers
Of your sudden mirth.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: Ha! ha! my lady has got
Such a guest at her table! − this term-driver, Marrall,
This snip of an attorney −

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: What of him, man?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: The knave feeds so slovenly!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Is this all?

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: My lady drank to him for fashion's sake,
Or to please Master Wellborn;
As I live, he rises, and takes up a dish
In which there were some remnants of a boil'd capon,
And pledges her in white broth!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: Nay, 'tis like
The rest of his tribe.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: And when I brought him wine,
He leaves his stool, and, after a leg or two,
Most humbly thanks my worship−my worship!

sp.speaker: All the Servants
sp.l: Ha ! ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.stage: (who has looked off at C. door to R.)
sp.l: Risen already!

sp.speaker: Furn.
sp.l: My lady frowns.

sp.speaker: Amb.
sp.l: I shall be chid.

div.stage: Exit Furnace, L.U.E.−Servants all run to L.
Enter Lady Allworth, Wellborn, and Marrall, C.D.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: You attend us well! To Amble, L.
Let me have no more of this; I observ'd your leering:
Sir, I will have you know, whom I think worthy
To sit at my table,
When I am present, is not your companion.

sp.speaker: Ord.
sp.l: Nay, she'll preserve what's due to her.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: To Wellborn You are master
Of your own will. I know so much of manners,
As not to inquire your purposes; in a word,
To me you are ever welcome, as to a house
That is your own. (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Mark that. to Marrall, L.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: With reverence, sir, and it like your worship.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Trouble yourself no further,
Dear madam; my heart's full of zeal and service,
However in my language I am sparing.
Come, Master Marrall. (crosses to L.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I attend your worship.

div.stage: Exeunt Watchall, Wellborn, and Marrall, L.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I see in your looks you are sorry, and you know me
An easy mistress: be merry; I have forgot all. −
Order and Amble, come with me; I must give you
Further directions.

div.head: Scene Third.−The open Country (2nd. grooves)
div.stage: Enter Wellborn, and Marrall, L. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I think I'm in a good way.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.stage: (who has his hat in his hand)
sp.l: Good, sir? the best way;
The certain best way.
You are worshipful−and I hope you will become right-worshipful.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Is't for your ease you keep your hat off?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Ease, and it like your worship!
I hope Jack Marrall shall not live so long,
To prove himself such an unmannerly beast,
Though it hail hazel-nuts, as to be covered
When your worship's present.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: asideIs not this a true rogue,
That, out of mere hope of a future coz'nage,
Can turn thus suddenly? 'tis rank already.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know your worship's wise, and needs no counsel,
Yet if, in my desire to do you service,
I humbly offer my advice, (but still
Under correction,) I hope I shall not
Incur your high displeasure.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: No; speak freely.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Then, in my judgment, sir, my simple judgment,
(Still with your worship's favour,) I could wish you
A better habit, for this cannot be
But much distasteful to the noble lady
That loves you:
I have twenty pounds here,
Which, out of my true love, I'll presently
Lay down at your worship's feet; 'twill serve to buy you
A riding suit.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: But where's the horse?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: My gelding
Is at your service: nay, you shall ride me,
Before your worship shall be put to the trouble
To walk afoot. Alas! when you are lord
Of this lady's manor, as I know you will be,
You may with the lease of glebe land, called Knave's-acre,
A place I would manure, requite your vassal.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I thank thy love, but will make no use of it;
Did I want clothes, think'st thou I could not have 'em,
For one word to my lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I know not that−

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Come, I'll tell thee a secret, and so leave thee.
I will not give her the advantage, though she be
A gallant-minded lady, after we're married,
To hit me in the teeth, and say, she was forc'd
To buy my wedding-clothes.−
No, I'll be furnished something like myself,
And so farewell: for thy suit touching Knave's-acre,
When it is mine, 'tis thine. Exit Wellborn

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I thank your worship. −
How was I cozen'd in the calculation
Of this man's fortune! my master cozen'd too,
Whose pupil I am in the art of undoing men;
For that is our profession! Well, well, Master Wellborn,
You are of a sweet nature, and fit again to be cheated:
Which, if the Fates please, when you are possessed
Of the land and lady, you, sans question, shall be.
I'll presently think of the means. (musing, R).

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Sirrah, take my horse.
I'll walk to get me an appetite; 'tis but a mile,
And exercise will keep me from being pursy. (enters L.)
Ha! Marrall! is he conjuring? Perhaps
The knave has wrought the prodigal to do
Some outrage on himself, and now he feels
Compunction in his conscience for't: no matter,
So it be done. − Marrall! Marrall!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: How succeed we in our plot on Wellborn?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Never better, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Has he hang'd or drown'd himself?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, sir, he lives;
Lives once more to be made a prey to you,
A greater prey than ever.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Art thou in thy wits?
If thou art, reveal this miracle, and briefly.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: A lady, sir, is fallen in love with him.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: With him? what lady?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: The rich Lady Allworth.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Thou dolt! how dar'st thou speak this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I speak truth.
And I do so but once a-year, unless
It be to you, sir: we din'd with her ladyship,
I thank his worship.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: His worship!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: As I live, sir,
I din'd with him, at the great lady's table,
Simple as I stand here; and saw when she kissed him,
And would, at his request, have kiss'd me too;

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Why, thou rascal!
To tell me these impossibilities.
Dine at her table! and kiss him! or thee! −
Impudent varlet, have not I myself,
Ten times attempted, since her husband's death,
In vain, to see her, though I came − a suitor?
And yet your good solicitorship, and rogue Wellborn,
Were brought into her presence, feasted with her! −
But that I know thee a dog that cannot blush,
This most incredible lie would call up one
On thy buttermilk cheeks.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Shall I not trust my eyes, sir,
Or taste? I feel her good cheer in my belly.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: You shall feel me, if you give not over, sirrah:
Recover your brains again, and be no more gulled
With a beggar's plot, assisted by the aids
Of serving-men and chambermaids;
Or I'll quit you from my employments.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will you credit this yet?
On my confidence of their marriage, I offered Wellborn −
(aside) I'd give a crown now I durst say his worship −
My nag, and twenty pounds.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Did you so, idiot? (strikes him)
Was this the way to work him to despair,
Or rather to cross me?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Will your worship kill me?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: No, no; but drive the lying spirit out of you.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: He's gone.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I've done then. Now, forgetting
Your late imaginary feast and lady,
Know, my Lord Lovell dines with me to-morrow.
Be careful nought be wanting to receive him;
And bid my daughter's women trim her up,
Though they paint her, so she catch the lord, I'll thank 'em:
There's a piece for my late blows. (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: aside, L. I may yet cry quittance;
There may be a time −

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Do you grumble?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, sir.

div.stage: Exeunt Sir Giles and Marrall, R.
div.note: If Performed in three Acts the First ends here.

div.head: SCENE First.−The Skirts of Lady Allworth's Park.
div.stage: Enter Lovell and Allworth, L.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Drive the coach round the hill: something in private
I must impart to Allworth.
[Exeunt Servants.]

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O, my lord,
What sacrifice of rev'rence, duty, watching,
Although I could put off the use of sleep,
And ever wait on your commands to serve 'em;
What dangers, though in ne'er so horrid shapes,
Nay death itself, though I should run to meet it,
Can I, and with a thankful willingness suffer!
But still the retribution will fall short
Of your bounties shower'd upon me.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Nay, good youth,
Till what I purpose be put into act,
Do not o'erprize it; since you've trusted me
With your soul's nearest, nay, her dearest secret,
Rest confident, 'tis in a cabinet lock'd
Treachery shall never open. I have found you
I will not be more true to mine own honour
Than to thee, Allworth!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Were you to encounter with a single foe,
The victory were certain; but to stand
The charge of two such potent enemies,
At once assaulting you, as wealth and beauty,
And those too seconded with power, is odds
Too great for Hercules.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Love hath made you poetical, Allworth.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Grant all these beat off,
(Which if it be in man to do, you'll do it,)
Mammon, in Sir Giles Overreach, steps in
With heaps of ill-got gold, and as much land,
As would tire
A falcon's wings in one day to fly over.
I here release your trust;
'Tis happiness enough for me to serve you
And sometimes, with chaste eyes, to look upon her.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Why, shall I swear?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O, by no means, my lord!
Suspend your judgment to the trial
How far is't to Overreach's house?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: At the most, some half hour's riding;
You'll soon be there.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: And you the sooner freed
From your jealous fears.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: O that I durst but hope it!

div.stage: Exeunt, R.

div.head: Scene Second.−The Hall in Sir Giles's House.
div.stage: Enter Sir Giles, Greedy, and Marrall, C. from L.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Spare for no cost; let my dressers crack with the weight
Of curious viands.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Store indeed's no sore, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: That proverb fits your stomach, Master Greedy.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.p: It does indeed, Sir Giles: I do not like to see a table ill-spread, poor, meagre, just sprinkled o'er with salads, slic'd beef, giblets, and pig's pettitoes. But the substantials−O, Sir Giles, the substantials! The state of a fat turkey now! the decorum, the grandeur, he marches in with! O, I declare I do much honor a chine of beef! O, I do reverence a loin of veal!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: And let no plate be seen, but what's pure gold,
Or such whose workmanship exceeds the matter
This is made of; let my choicest linen
Perfume the room, and, when we wash, the water,
With precious powders mixed, so please my lord,
That he may with envy wish to bathe so ever.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: 'Twill be very chargeable.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Avaunt, you drudge!
Now all my labour'd ends are at the stake,
Is't a time to think of thrift? Call in my daughter.
And, master justice, since you love choice dishes,
And plenty of 'em −

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: As I do, indeed, sir,
Almost as much as to give thanks for 'em.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I do confer that providence, with my power
Of absolute command to have abundance,
To your best care.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: I'll punctually discharge it,
And give the best directions.−(Sir Giles retires up the stage)
Now am I,
In mine own conceit, a monarch; at the least,
Arch-president o' the boiled, the roast, the bak'd;
I'd not change my throne for the Great Mogul's;
For which I will eat often, and give thanks
When my belly's brac'd up like a drum; and that's pure justice. Exit Greedy, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: It must be so: should the foolish girl prove modest,
She may spoil all; she had it not from me,
But from her mother; I was ever forward,
As she must be, and therefore I'll prepare her.
sp.stage: Enter Marrall, followed by Margaret, and two Female Attendants, L.
sp.l: Alone, Margaret−
Alone − and let your women wait without.

div.stage: Exit Women and Marrall, L.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Your pleasure, sir?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Ha! this is a neat dressing!
sp.stage: (walks round her, and remains on her L.)
sp.l: These orient pearls and diamonds well plac'd too!
The gown affects me not, it should have been
Embroidered o'er and o'er with flowers of gold;
But these rich jewels and quaint fashion help it.
Invites as much as perfect white and red,
How like you your new woman,
The Lady Downfallen?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Well, for a companion;
Not as a servant.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Is she humble, Meg,
And careful too, "Her Ladyship" forgotten?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I pity her fortune.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Pity her! trample on her.
I took her up in an old tamin gown,
E'en starv'd for very want of food, to serve thee,
And if I understand she but repines
To do thee any duty, though ne'er so servile,
I'll pack her to her knight, where I have lodg'd him,
Into the counter, and there let e'em howl together.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You know your own ways; but for me, I blush
When I command her, that was once attended
With persons not inferior to myself
In birth.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: In birth! why, art thou not my daughter,
The blest child of my industry and wealth?
Part with these humble thoughts, and apt thyself
To the noble state I labour to advance thee;
Or, by my hopes to see thee honourable,
I will adopt a stranger to my heir,
And throw thee from my care.−Do not provoke me.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I will not, sir; mould me which way you please.

div.stage: Enter Greedy, R. with a napkin round his neck, and a dumpling in his hand.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Sir Giles, Sir Giles−

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: How! interrupted? (crosses to him)

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: 'Tis matter of importance.
The cook, sir, is self-will'd, and will not learn
From my experience. There's a fawn brought in, sir,
And, for my life, I cannot make him roast it whole
With a Norfolk dumpling in the belly of it;
And, sir, we wise men know, without the dumpling
'Tis not worth three-pence.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Would it were whole in thy belly,
To stuff it out! cook it any way; Pr'ythee, leave me.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Without order for the dumpling?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Let it be dumpled
Which way thou wilt; or tell him, I will scald him
In his own cauldron.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: I had lost my stomach
Had I lost my dumpling. Exit Greedy, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: But to our business, Meg; you've heard who dines here?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I have, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Tis an honourable man;
A lord, Meg, and commands a regiment
Of soldiers, and, what's rare, is one himself,
A bold and understanding one: and to be
A lord, and a good leader, in one volume,
Is granted unto few but such as rise up
The kingdom's glory.

div.stage: Re-enter Greedy, R. with a toast and fork.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: I'll resign my office,
If I be not better obey'd.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Slight, art thou frantic?

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Frantic! 'twould make me frantic, and stark mad,
Were I not a justice of peace and quorum too,
Which this rebellious cook cares not a straw for.
There are a dozen of woodcocks −
He has found out
A new device for sauce, and will not dish 'em
With toasts and butter.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Cook! − rogue, obey him!
I've given the word: pray, now remove yourself
To a collar of brawn, and trouble me no further.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: I will, and meditate what to eat at dinner. Exit Greedy, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: And as I said, Meg, when this gull disturb'd us,
This honourable lord, this colonel,
I would have thy husband.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: There's too much disparity
Between his quality and mine, to hope it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I more than hope, and doubt not to effect it;
Be thou no enemy to thyself; my wealth
Shall weigh his titles down, and make you equals.
Now for the means to assure him thine, observe me;
Remember he's a courtier, and a soldier,
And not to be trifled with; and, therefore, when
He comes to woo you, see you do not coy it:
This mincing modesty hath spoil'd many a match
By a first refusal, in vain after hop'd for.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: You'll have me, sir, preserve the distance that
Confines a virgin?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Virgin me no virgins!
I'll have you lose that name, or you lose me;
I'll have you private − start not − I say, private;
If thou art my true daughter, not a bastard,
You'll venture alone with one man, though he came
Like Jupiter to Semele, and come off, too;
And therefore, when he kisses you, kiss close.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I have heard this is the wanton's fashion, sir,
Which I must never learn.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Learn any thing,
And from any creature that may make thee great;
E'en from the devil himself; stand not on form;
Words are no substances.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: With your leave, sir−in worldly policy
This is not the way to make me his wife:
My maiden scruples overcome so soon,
Cannot but assure him
I, that am light to him, will not hold weight
When tempted by others; so, in judgment,
If, to obey you, I forget my honour,
He must and will forsake me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: How! forsake thee!
Do I wear a sword for fashion? or is this arm
Shrunk up or wither'd? Does there live a man
Of that large list I have encounter'd with
Can truly say I e'er gave inch of ground
Not purchas'd with his blood that did oppose me?
Forsake thee!−he dares not.
Though all his captains, echoes to his will,
Stood arm'd by his side, to justify the wrong;
Spite of his lordship, and his colonelship,
I would make him render
A bloody and a strict account, and force him,
By marrying thee, to cure thy wounded honour!
I have said it. (crosses to L.)

div.stage: Enter Marrall, hastily, C. from L.U.E.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, sir, the man of honour's come,
Newly alighted.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: In there, without reply, and wait my call:
And do as I command, or thou art lost.
What! is the loud music I gave order for
Ready to receive him?

sp.speaker: Marr.
sp.l: 'Tis, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Let 'em sound
A princely welcome.
Roughness, awhile leave me;
For fawning now, a stranger to my nature,
Must make way for me. (music)

div.stage: Enter Marrall, Lovell, and Allworth, C. from L.U.E. preceded and followed by Servants.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Sir, you meet your trouble.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: What you are pleas'd to style so, is an honour
Above my worth and fortunes.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: L., asideStrange! so humble!

div.stage: Re-enter Greedy, R. with a napkin under his chin.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Faugh! (points to napkin, which Greedy instantly snatches off and puts behind him) A justice of peace, my lord. presents Greedy to him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Your hand, good sir.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: C.−asideThis is a lord, and some would think this a favour;
But I had rather have my hand in my dumpling,

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Room for my lord.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I miss, sir, your fair daughter,
To crown my welcome.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: May it please my lord
To taste a glass of Greek wine first; and suddenly
She shall attend my lord.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You'll be obeyed, sir.

div.stage: Exeunt all but Overreach

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Tis to my wish: as soon as come, ask for her! −
Why, Meg! Meg Overreach. −
How! tears in your eyes!
Hah! dry 'em quickly, or I'll dig 'em out.
Is this a time to whimper? meet that greatness
That flies into thy bosom; think what 'tis
For me to say, my honourable daughter;
No moreb ut be instructed, or expect −
sp.stage: Enter Lovell, Allworth, Greedy, and Marrall, L.
sp.l: A well form'd girl, my lord.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: As I live, a rare one.(salutes her)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: (aside)He's ta'en already: I am lost.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: That kiss
Came twanging off; I like it:−Quit the room. −
sp.stage: Exeunt Greedy, Marrall, and Allworth, R.
sp.l: A little bashful, my good lord, but you,
I hope, will teach her boldness.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I am happy
In such a scholar: but −

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I am too old to learn,
And therefore leave you to yourselves: − (crosses to R.)
Remember! aside to Margaret and exit, R.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You see, fair lady, your father is solicitous,
To have you change the barren name of virgin
Into a hopeful wife.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: His haste, my lord,
Holds no power o'er my will.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: But o'er your duty.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Which, forc'd too much, may break.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Bend rather, sweetest:
Think of your years.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Too few to match with yours:

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I can advance you.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: To a hill of sorrow;
Where every hour I may expect to fall,
But never hope firm footing. You are noble,
I of a low descent, however rich;
O, my good lord, I could say more, but that
I dare not trust these walls.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Pray you, trust my ear then. (they whisper up stage)

div.stage: Re-enter Sir Giles, listening, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Close at it! whispering!−this is excellent!
And, by their postures, a consent on both parts.

div.stage: Re-enter Greedy, R.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Sir Giles, Sir Giles!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: The great fiend stop that clapper!

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: It must ring out, sir, when my belly rings noon.
The bak'd-meats are run out, the roast turn'd powder.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Stop your insatiate jaws, or
I shall powder you.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Beat me to dust, I care not;
In such a cause as this, I'll die a martyr.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Disturb my lord,
When he is in discourse?

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Is't a time to talk
When we should be munching?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Mum, villain; vanish! shall we break a bargain
Almost made up?

div.stage: Exit, thrusting Greedy off before him, R.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Lady, I understand you,
And wish you happy in your choice; believe it;
I'll be a careful pilot to direct
Your yet uncertain bark to a port of safety.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: So shall your honour save two lives, and bind us
Your slaves forever.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I'm in the act rewarded,
Since it is good; howe'er, you must put on
An amorous carriage towards me till our purpose
Be brought to the wish'd end.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'm prone to that.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Now break we off our conference. − Sir Giles!
Where is Sir Giles? (coming forward)

div.stage: Enter Sir Giles, Allworth, Greedy, and Marrall, R. Allworth crosses behind to L.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: My noble lord; and how
Does your lordship find her?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Apt, Sir Giles, and coming;
And I like her the better.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: So do I too.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Yet should we take forts at the first assault,
'Twere poor in the defendant; I will confirm her
With a love-letter or two, which I shall have
Deliver'd by my page: we must, for form, give way to't.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: With all my soul: − a towardly gentleman!
Your hand, good Master Allworth; know my house
Is ever open to you.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: (aside)] ‘Twas shut till now.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Well done, well done, my honourable daughter!
Thou'rt so already; (leading Margaret over to Allworth) know this gentle youth,
And cherish him, (aside to her)my honourable daughter!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I shall, with my best care.

sp.speaker: Servants
sp.l: Room, room−make way there for my lady.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: What noise?

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: More stops
Before we go to dinner! O my belly!

div.stage: Enter six Servants, Lady Allworth and Wellborn, C.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: If I find welcome,
You shall share in't; if not, I'll back again,
For I come arm'd for all can be objected.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: How! the Lady Allworth? (crosses to her)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: And thus attended!

div.stage: (Lovell presents Margaret to Lady Allworth)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No, I am a dolt! (aside to Sir Giles)
The spirit of lies hath enter'd me!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Peace, Patch!
'Tis more than wonder! an astonishment
That does possess me wholly!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Noble lady,
This is a favour, to prevent my visit,
The service of my life can never equal.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: My lord, I laid wait for you, and much hoped
You would have made my poor house your first inn:
And therefore doubting that you might forget me,
I borrowed so much from my long restraint
And took the air, in person to invite you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Your bounties are so great, they rob me, madam,
Of words to give you thanks.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: Good Sir Giles Overreach. − (bows to him)
How dost thou, Marrall? − lik'd you my meat so ill,
You'll dine no more with me?

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: I will, when you please,
An it like your ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: When you please, Master Greedy;
If meat can do't, you shall be satisfied. −
And now, my lord, pray take into your knowledge
This gentleman; howe'er his outside's coarse,
His inward linings are as fine and fair
As any man's;
And howsoe'er his humour carries him
To be thus accoutred, or what taint soe'er,
For his wild life, hath stuck upon his fame,
He may, ere long, with boldness, rank himself
With some that have contemn'd him. Sir Giles Overreach,
If I am welcome, bid him so.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: My nephew! (crosses to Wellborn, L.)
He has been too long a stranger: faith you have,
Pray let it be mended. (shakes both his hands)

div.stage: all converse apart−Sir Giles meets Marrall, R)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Why, sir, what do you mean?
This is rogue Wellborn, monster, prodigy,
That should hang or drown himself; no man of worship,
Much less "your nephew."

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Well, sirrah, we shall reckon
For this hereafter.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I'll not lose my joke,
Though I be beaten dead for't. (retires up the stage)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Let my silence plead
In my excuse, my lord, till better leisure
Offer itself to hear a full relation
Of my poor fortunes.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I would hear, and help 'em.

sp.speaker: Greedy
sp.l: Ah!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Your dinner waits you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Pray you lead, we follow.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Dear Master Wellborn, come :−You are my guest.(takes Wellborn's hand)

div.stage: Music.−Exeunt all but Greedy, R.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Dear Master Wellborn! So she said: Good heaven!
If my belly would give me leave, I could ruminate
All day on this: I've granted twenty warrants
To have him committed, from all prisons in the shire,
To Nottingham gaol; and now, "Dear Master Wellborn!"
And, "My good nephew!" − But I play the fool
To stand here prating, and forget my dinner. (going, R.)
Are they set, Marrall!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Long since. Greedy going R. Marrall prevents him) Pray you, a word, sir.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: No wording now.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: In troth, I must; my master,
Knowing you are his good friend, makes bold with you.
And does entreat you, more guests being come in
Than he expected, especially his nephew,
The table being full too, you would excuse him,
And sup with him on the cold meat.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: How! no dinner,
After all my care?

sp.speaker: Mar. '
sp.l: 'Tis but a penance for
A meal; besides, you broke your fast.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: That was
But a bit to stay my stomach: a man in commission
Give place to a tatterdemalion?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: No big words, sir;
Should his worship hear you −

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Lose my dumpling too,
And butter'd toasts, and woodcocks?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Come, have patience.
If you will dispense a little with your Justiceship,
And sit with the maids below there, you'll have dumpling,
Woodcock, and butter'd toast too, by and by.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: This revives me:
I will gorge there sufficiently.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: There's your way, sir.

div.stage: Exit Marrall, R.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.p: I fear, we shall have but short commons below. I am no cameleon, to feed on air; nor Frenchman, to feast on a soused frog, or regale on an ounce of beef in a Mediterranean sea of soup: I love to see the board well spread, groaning under its savoury burden, smoking-hot, from spit, furnace., and cauldron. - Ods-me, Sir Giles! Exit, L.

div.stage: Enter Sir Giles, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: She's caught! O women! − What, neglect my lord,
And all her compliments apply to Wellborn!
The garments of her widowhood laid by,
She now appears as glorious as the spring,
Her eyes fix'd on him, in the wine she drinks,
He being her pledge, she sends him burning kisses,
And sits on thorns, till she be private with him.
She leaves my meat to feed upon his looks;
And if in our discourse he be but nam'd,
From her a deep sigh follows. But why grieve I
At this? it makes for me; if she prove his,
All that is hers is mine, as I will work him.

div.stage: Enter Marrall, R.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, the whole board is troubled at your rising.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: No matter, I'll excuse it: pr'ythee, Marrall,
Watch an occasion to invite my nephew
To speak with me in private.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Who? the rogue
The lady scorn'd to look on?"

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Sirrah, sirrah! (crosses)

div.stage: Enter Lovell, Margaret, and Allworth, R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: My good lord, excuse my manners.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: There needs none, Sir Giles,
I may ere long say−father, when it please
My dearest mistress to give warrant to it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: She shall seal to it, my lord, and make me happy.

sp.speaker: Marr.
sp.l: See, sir, she comes and cannot be without him.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Grosser and grosser!
sp.stage: (goes L.−Marrall crosses behind to R. and Margaret goes to R. of Allworth)

div.stage: Enter Lady Allworth, Wellborn and Servants, R.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Provide my coach, Exit Servant, C.
I'll instantly away; − my thanks, Sir Giles,
For my entertainment.

div.stage: (Marrall whispers Wellborn, R.)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Tis your nobleness
To think it such.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I must do you a further wrong
In taking away your honourable guest.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I wait on you, madam; farewell, good Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Nay, come, Master Wellborn,
I must not leave you behind; in sooth, I must not.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Rob me not, madam, of all joys at once;
Let my nephew stay behind: he shall have my coach,
And, after some small conference between us,
Soon overtake your ladyship.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Stay not so long, sir.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Farewell, dear Margaret! You shall every day
Hear from your servant, by my faithful page.

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.l: 'Tis a service I am proud of. (music)

div.stage: Exeunt Lovell, Lady Allworth, Allworth, and Servants, C. to L.U.E.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Daughter, to your chamber. −
− You may wonder, nephew,
After so long an enmity between us,
I should desire your friendship.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: So I do, sir;
'Tis strange to me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: But I'll make it no wonder;
And what is more, unfold my nature to you.
We worldly men, when we see friends and kinsmen
Past hope sunk in their fortunes, lend no hand
To lift them up, but rather set our feet
Upon their heads, to press them to the bottom;
As, I must yield, with you I practis'd it:
But, now I see you in a way to rise,
I can and will assist you. This rich lady
(And I am glad of 't) is enamoured of you;

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: No such thing:
Compassion rather, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Well, in a word,
Because your stay is short, I'll have you seen
No more in this base shape; nor shall she say,
She married you like a beggar, or in debt.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: (aside) He'll run into the noose, and save my labour.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: You have a trunk of rich clothes, not far hence,
In pawn; I will redeem them; and that no clamour
May taint your credit for your petty debts,
You shall have wherwithal to cut 'em off,
And go a freeman to the wealthy lady.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: This done, sir, out of love, and no ends else −

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: As it is, nephew.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Binds me still your servant.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: No compliments, you're staid for: ere you've supp'd
You shall hear from me. − My coach, knaves, for my nephew!
To-morrow I will visit you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Here's an uncle
In a man's extremes! how much they do belie you,
That say you are hard-hearted!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: My deeds, nephew,
Shall speak my love; what men report I weigh not.

div.stage: Exeunt Wellborn, C. Sir Giles, R.

div.head: ACT IV.
Scene First.−A Room in Lady Allworth's House.−Table and two chairs, pens, ink, paper, wax, and lighted taper.
div.stage: Lovell discovered, seated R., sealing a letter, and Allworth waiting on him.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: 'Tis well.−May this succeed!
I now discharge you
From further service: mind your own affairs,
I hope they'll prove successful.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: My lord, I want language
To speak my debt; yet if a tear or two
Of joy, for your much goodness, can supply
My tongue's defects, I could −

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Nay,
This ceremonial thanks to me's superfluous.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: (without, L)] Is my lord stirring?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: 'Tis he! oh, here's your letter:
sp.stage: (takes the letter from the table and gives it to Allworth)
sp.l: Let him in.
sp.stage: (Allworth opens the door, L. and stands retired)

div.stage: Enter Sir Giles, Greedy, and Marrall, L.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: A good day to my lord!

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You are an early riser,
Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: And reason to attend your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: And you, too, Master Greedy, up so soon!

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: In troth, my lord, after the sun is up,
I cannot sleep, for I have a foolish stomach
That croaks for breakfast. With your lordship's favour, (crosses to Lovell, R.C.)
I have a serious question to demand
Of my worthy friend Sir Giles.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Pray you use your pleasure. (retires up the stage)

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: How far, Sir Giles, and pray you answer me
Upon your credit, hold you it to be
From your manor-house, to this of my Lady's Allworth's?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Why, some four mile.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: How! four mile, good Sir Giles −
Upon your reputation, think better;
For four miles riding
Could not have raised so huge an appetite
As I feel gnawing on me.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Whether you ride,
Or go afoot, you're that way still provided,
An't please your worship.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: How now, sirrah? Prating
Before my lord! no deference! Go to my nephew,
See all his debts discharged, and help his worship
To fit on his rich suit.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I may fit you too. Exit Marrall, L.D.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I have writ this morning
A few lines to my mistress, your fair daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Twill fire her, for she's wholly your's already: −
Sweet Master Allworth, take my ring; 'twill carry you
To her presence, I dare warrant you; and there plead
For my good lord, if you should find occasion.
That done, pray ride to Nottingham, get a license,
Still by this token.−(to Lovell)I will have't dispatch'd,
And suddenly, my lord, that I may say,
My honourable, nay, right honourable daughter.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.stage: (stopping Allworth, who is crossing towards L.D.
sp.l: Take my advice, young gentleman, get your breakfast;
'Tis unwholesome to ride fasting: I'll eat with you,
And that abundantly

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Some fury's in that gut:
Hungry again! did you not devour, this morning,
A shield of brawn, and a barrel of Colchester oysters?

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Why, that was, sir, only to scour my stomach,
A kind of a preparative.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Haste your return.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I will not fail, my lord. Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Nor I, to line
My Christmas coffer. Exit, L.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: To my wish: (they sit); we're private.
I come not to make offer with my daughter
A certain portion, that were poor and trivial:
In one word, I pronounce all that is mine,
In lands or leases, ready coin or goods,
With her, my lord, comes to you; nor shall you have
One motive to induce you to believe
I live too long, since every year I'll add
Something unto the heap, which shall be your's too.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You are a right kind father.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: You shall have reason
To think me such.
How do you like this seat of Lady Allworth's??
It is well wooded, and well water'd, the acres
Fertile and rich; would it not serve, for change,
To entertain your friends in a summer progress?
What thinks my noble lord?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: 'Tis a wholesome air,
And well-built pile; and she that's mistress of it,
Worthy the large revénue.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: She the mistress!
It may be so for a time: but let my lord
Say only that he likes it, and would have it,
I say, ere long 'tis his.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Impossible!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: You do conclude too fast, not knowing me,
Nor the engines that I work by. ‘Tis not alone
The Lady Allworth's lands, for those once Wellborn's,
As by her dotage on him I know they will be,
Shall soon be mine;−but point out any man's
In all the shire, and say they lie convenient,
And useful for your lordship, and once more
I say aloud, they're yours.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I dare not own
What's by unjust and cruel means extorted;
My fame and credit are more dear to me,
Than so to expose 'em to be censur'd by
The public voice.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: You run, my lord, no hazard.
sp.stage: (leans on the back of the chair)
sp.l: Your reputatiön shall stand as fair,
In all good men's opiniöns, as now;
For, though I do contemn report myself
As a mere sound, I still will be so tender
Of what concerns you, in all points of honour,
That the immaculate whiteness of your fame,
Shall ne'er be sullied with one taint or spot.
All my ambition is to have my daughter
Right honourable, which my lord can make her:
And might I live to dance upon my knee
A young Lord Lovell, born by her unto you,
I write nil ultra to my proudest hopes. (goes L.)
As for possession and annual rents,
Equivalent to maintain you in the port
Your noble birth and present state requires,
I do remove that burden from your shoulders,
And take it on mine own: for, though I ruin
The country to supply your riotous waste,
The scourge of prodigals, want, shall never find you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Are you not mov'd with the sad imprecations
And curses of whole families, made wretched
By your sinister practices?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Yes, as rocks are,
When foamy billows split themselves against
Their flinty ribs; or as the moon is moved,
When wolves, with hunger pin'd, howl at her brightness.
I'm of a solid temper, and, like these,
Steer on, a constant course.
Nay, when my ears are pierc'd with widows' cries,
And undone orphans wash with tears my threshold,
I only think what 'tis to have my daughter
Right honourable; and 'tis a powerful charm
Makes me insensible of remorse, or pity,
Or the least sting of conscience.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I admire
The toughness of your nature.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: 'Tis for you,
My lord, and for my daughter, I am marble;
Nay more, if you will have my character
In little, I enjoy more true delight
In my arrival to my wealth these dark
And crooked ways than you shall e'er take pleasure
In spending what my industry hath compassed.
My haste commands me hence; in one word, therefore,
Is it a match, my lord?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I hope, that is past doubt now.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Then rest secure; not the hate of all mankind here,
Nor fear of what can fall on me hereafter,
Shall make me study aught but your advancement
One story higher: an earl! if gold can do it.
Doubt not my honour, nor my faith to you;
Though I am borne thus headlong by my will,
You may make choice of what belief you please,
To me 'tis equal; so, my lord, good morrow.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: He's gone − I wonder how the earth can bear him!
I, that have lived a soldier,
And stood the enemy's violent charge undaunted,
To hear this horrid monster, am all bathed
In a cold sweat: yet, like a mountain, he
(Confirmed in atheistical assertions)
Is no more shaken than OlympusAn error. Parnassus has a "double head," Olympus has not. is
When angry Boreas loads his double head
With sudden drifts of snow.

div.stage: Enter Lady Allworth,C.D.−advances, R.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Save you, my lord!
