Disturb I not your privacy?

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: No, good madam;
For your own sake I am glad you came no sooner,
Since this bold bad man, Sir Giles Overreach,
Made such a plain discovery of himself,
And read this morning such a devilish matins,
That I should think it a sin next to his
But to repeat it.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I ne'er pressed, my lord,
On others' privacies; yet, against my will,
Walking, for health's sake, in the gallery here
I was made
(So loud and vehement he was) partaker
Of his tempting offers.
But, my good lord: if I may use my freedom,
As to an honoured friend −

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You lessen else
Your favour to me.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I dare, then, say thus;
However common men
Make sordid wealth the object and sole end
Of their industrious aims, 'twill not agree
With those of noble blood, of fame, and honour.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Madam, 'tis confessed;
But what infer you from it?

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: This, my lord;
I allow the heir of Sir Giles Overreach, Margaret,
A maid well qualified and the richest match
Our north part can make boast of; yet she cannot,
With all that she brings with her, stop their mouths,
That never will forget who was her father;
Or that my husband Allworth's lands, and Wellborn's,
(How wrung from both needs now no repetition,)
Were real motives that more worked your lordship
To join your families, than her form and virtues:
You may conceive the rest.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I do, sweet madam,
And long since have consider'd it.
And 'tis my resolution ne'er to wed
With the rich Margaret, Overreach's daughter.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: (aside) I'm glad to hear this.
Why then, my lord, pretend you marriage to her?
Dissimulation but ties false knots
On that straight line by which you, hitherto,
Have measur'd all your actions.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I make answer,
And aptly, with a question. Wherefore have you,
That, since your husband's death, have lived a strict
And chaste nun's life, on the sudden given yourself
To visits and entertainments? Think you, madam,
'Tis not grown public conference; or the favours
Which you so prodigally have thrown on Wellborn,
Incur not censure?

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I am innocent here; and, on my life, I swear
My ends are good.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: So, on my soul, are mine
To Margaret; but leave both to the event:
And since this friendly privacy does serve
As a fair offer'd means unto ourselves,
To search each other further, you having shewn
Your care of me, I my respect to you−
Deny me not, I dare not yet say more,
An afternoon's discourse.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: Affected coyness might deny your suit;
But such your honour, frankness shall become me,
And bid my tongue avow my honest heart:
I shall attend your lordship.

sp.speaker: Lovel.
sp.l: My heartthanks you.

div.stage: Exeunt Lovel, L. Lady Allworth.

div.head: Scene Second.−A Village (same as Act I, Scene I.)
div.stage: Enter Froth and Tapwell, from the house, L.2.E.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Undone, undone! this was your counsel, Froth.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Mine! I defy thee: did not Master Marrall−
He has marr'd all, I am sure−strictly command us,
On pain of Sir Giles Overreach's displeasure,
To turn the gentleman out of doors?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: ‘Tis true;
But now, he's his uncle's darling; and has got
Master Justice Greedy, since he fill'd his belly,
At his commandment, to do anything.
Woe, woe to us!

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: He may prove merciful.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Froth, we do not deserve it at his hands.

sp.speaker: Froth
sp.l: Then, he knew all the passages of our house,
As the receiving of stolen goods, and so forth.
When he was rogue Wellborn, no man would believe him;
And then his information could not hurt us;
But now he is right worshipful again,
Who dares but doubt his testimony?

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Undone, undone! Methinks
I see thee, Froth, already in a cart,
And my hand hissing,
If I 'scape the halter, with the letter R
Printed upon it.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Would that were the worst!
That were but nine days wonder: as for credit,
We've none to lose; but we shall lose his custom:
There's the devil on't.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: He has summon'd all his creditors by the drum;
'Tis said, he has found such a new way
To pay his old debts, as 'tis very likely,
He shall be chronicled for it!

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: But are you sure his worship
Comes this way, to my lady's?−
sp.stage: (drum−and shout without of−"Brave Master Wellborn!" L.U.E.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Hark, I hear him.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: Be ready with your petition, and present it
To his good grace.

div.stage: Enter Greedy, Wellborn in a rich habit, Marrall−Vintner, Tailor, with other creditors−Order, Furnace, and Amble, L.U.E. followed by −Tapwell and Froth, kneeling, R., deliver a petition.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: How's this? petition'd too!
But note what miracles the payment of
A little trash, and a rich suit of clothes,
Can work upon these rascals! I shall be,
I think, Prince Wellborn.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: When your worship's married,
You may be − I know ; what I hope to see you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Then look thou for advancement.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: To be known
Your worship's bailiff, is the mark I shoot at.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: And thou shalt hit it.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Pray you, sir, dispatch
These needy followers: and for my admittance,
sp.stage: (Tapwell and Froth flattering Justice Greedy, R.)
sp.l: Provided you'll defend me from Sir Giles,
Whose service I am weary of, I'll say something
You shall give thanks for.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Fear not Sir Giles.

div.stage: (Wellborn and Marrall retire up on L.C. and converse apart)

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Who? Tapwell?−I remember thy wife brought me,
Last new-year's tide, a couple of fat turkeys.

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: And shall do every Christmas, let your worship
But stand my friend now.

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: How! with Master Wellborn?
I can do anything with him on such terms. −
See you this honest couple, they're good souls
As ever drew out spigot: have they not
A pair of honest faces?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I o'erheard you,
And the bribe he promis'd. You are cozen'd in 'em;
For, of all the scum that grew rich by my riots,
This, for a most unthankful knave, and this,
For a base quean and thief, have worst deserv'd me;
And therefore speak not for them. By your place
You are rather to do me justice. Lend me your ear: −
Forget his turkeys, and call in his license,
And every season I will send you venison,
To feast a mayor and corporation.
sp.stage: (goes a little up, and converses with Marrall)

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: I am chang'd o' the sudden in my opinion−Mum.
Come near; (to Tapwell and Froth) nearer, rascal!
And, now I view him better, did you e'er see
One look so like an arch knave? his very countenance,
Should an understanding Judge but look upon him,
Would hang him, though he were innocent.

sp.speaker: Tap. and Froth.
sp.l: Worshipful sir−

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: No, though the great Turk came, instead of turkeys,
To beg my favour, I'm inexorable.
Thou'st an ill name: I here do damn thy license,
Forbidding thee ever to tap or draw;
For instantly I will, in mine own person,
Command the constable to pull down thy sign,
And do't before I eat.

sp.speaker: Froth.
sp.l: No mercy?

sp.speaker: Greedy.
sp.l: Vanish!−
If I shew any, may my promis'd venison choke me!

sp.speaker: Tap.
sp.l: Unthankful knaves are ever so rewarded.
sp.stage: Exit with Froth into the house, L.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: On, Master Greedy : I'll be with you at dinner.

sp.speaker: Greedy
sp.l: For heaven's sake, don't stay long;
'Tis almost ready. Exit Greedy, R.
[Exeunt Greedy, Tapwell, and Froth.]

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Speak; what are you?

sp.speaker: Vintner.
sp.l: A decayed vintner, sir,
That might have thrived, but that your worship broke me
With trusting you with muscadine and eggs,
And five pound suppers, with your after-drinkings,
When you lodg'd upon the Bankside.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I remember.

sp.speaker: 1st Cred.
sp.l: I've not been hasty, nor e'er laid to arrest you;
And therefore, sir −

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Thou art an honest fellow,
I'll set thee up again;(Vintner goes up centre) -- (to Marrall) See his bill paid. −
What are you?

sp.speaker: Tailor
sp.l: A tailor once, but now mere botcher.
I long time gave you credit for rich clothes:
But, you failing in payment,
I was remov'd from the shop-board, and confin'd
Under a stall.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: See him paid; (to Marrall) and botch no more.

sp.speaker: Tailor.
sp.l: I ask no interest, sir.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Such tailors need not;
If their bills are paid in one and twenty years,
They're seldom losers. See these men discharg'd.
sp.stage: (Marrall motions to the Creditors to imply he will do so)
sp.l: And since old debts are clear'd by a new way,
A little bounty will not misbecome me:
There's something for you all.

sp.speaker: All the Creditors
sp.l: Brave Master Wellborn!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Leave me, good friends: attend upon your lady.
sp.stage: Exeunt Amble, Furnace, and Order, R.
sp.l: Now, Master Marrall, what's the weighty secret
You promis'd to impart?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, time nor place
Allow me to relate each circumstance,
This only, in a word; I know Sir Giles
Will come upon you for security
For all the money which he now has lent you;
This you must not consent to.
As he grows in heat, as I am sure he will;
Be you but rough, and say he's in your debt
Ten times the sum, upon sale of your land:
I had a hand in't, I speak it to my shame,
When you were defeated of it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: That's forgiven.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I shall deserve it−Then urge him to produce
The deed in which you pass'd it over to him;
Which, I know, he'll have about him, to deliver
To the Lord Lovell. I'll instruct you further,
As I wait on your worship: if I play not my prize
To your full content, and your uncle's much vexation,
Hang up Jack Marrall.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I rely upon thee.

div.stage: Exeunt, R.

div.head: Scene Third.−A room in Sir Giles's house. Table and two chairs−pen, ink, and paper.
div.stage: Enter Margaret, with a letter in her hand, and Allworth, R.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Whether to yield the first praise to my lord's
Unequalled temperance, or your constant sweetness,
I yet rest doubtful.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Give it to Lord Lovell;
For what in him was bounty, in me's duty.
To me what's title, when content is wanting?
Or the smooth brow, and wealth
Of a pleas'd sire, that slaves me to his will;
And, so his vain ambition may be feasted
By my obedience, and he see me great,
Leaves to my soul nor faculties nor power
To make her own election?

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: But the dangers
That follow the repulse −

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: To me they're nothing;
Let Allworth love, I cannot be unhappy.
Suppose the worst−that, in his rage, he kill me;
A tear or two, by you dropt on my hearse,
In sorrow for my fate, will call back life
So far as but to say, that I die your's;
I then shall rest in peace.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Heaven avert
Such trials of your true affection to me!
Nor will it unto you, that are all mercy,
Show so much rigour. But since we must run
Such desperate hazards, let us do our best
To steer between 'em.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Lord Lovell is our friend;
And, though but a young actor, second me
In doing to the life what he has plotted,
The end may yet prove happy.−(aside) - Now, my Allworth.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: To your letter, and put on a seeming anger.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I'll pay my lord all debts due to his title;
And when with terms, not taking from his honour,
He does solicit me, I shall gladly hear him.
But in this peremptory, nay, commanding way,
To fix a time and place, without my knowledge,
A priest to tie the knot can ne'er be undone
Till death unloose it, is a confidence
In his lordship will deceive him. (crosses to R.)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I hope better, good lady.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Hope, sir, what you please: for me,
I must take a safe and secure course; I have
A father, and without his full consent,
Though all lords of the land kneel'd for my favour,
I can grant nothing. (crosses to L.)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I like this obedience;
But whatsoe'er my lord writes, must and shall be
Accepted and embrac'd.−(advances to centre)−Sweet Master Allworth,
You shew yourself a true and faithful servant
To your good lord; he has a jewel of you.
How! frowning, Meg? are these looks to receive
A messenger from my lord? what's this? give me it.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: A piece of arrogant paper!
"Fair mistress, from your servant learn all joys
That we can hope for, if deferr'd, prove toys;
Therefore this instant, and in private, meet
A husband, that will gladly at your feet
Lay down his honours, tendering them to you
With all content, the church being paid her due." −

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Is this the arrogant piece of paper? fool!
Will you still be one? I'the name of madness, what
Could his good honour write more to content you?
Is there aught else to be wished, after these two,
That are already offered? Marriage first,
And lawful pleasure after;−what would you more?

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Why, sir, I would be married like your daughter;
Not hurried away i'the night I know not whither,
Without all ceremony; no friends invited
To honour the solemnity.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: An't please your honour,
For so before to-morrow I must style you,
My lord desires this privacy, in respect
His honourable kinsmen are far off,
And his desires to have to done, brook not
So long delay as to expect their coming;
And yet he stands resolved, with all due pomp,
To have his marriage at court celebrated,
When he has brought your honour up to London.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: He tells you true; 'tis the fashion, on my knowledge:
Yet the good lord, to please your peevishness,
Must put it off, forsooth!

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: I could be contented,
Were you but by, to do a father's part,
And give me in the church.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: So my lord have you,
What do I care who gives you? Since my lord
Does purpose to be private, I'll not cross him.
I know not, Master Allworth, how my lord
May be provided, and therefore there's a purse
Of gold, 'twill serve this night's expense; to-morrow
I'll furnish him with any sums.
Use my ring to my chaplain; he is beneficed
At my manor of Got'em, and called Parson Willdo:
'Tis no matter for a licence, I'll bear him out in't.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: With your favour, sir−what warrant is your ring?
He may suppose I got that twenty ways,
Without your knowledge; and then to be refus'd
Were such a stain upon me! − if you pleas'd, sir,
Your presence would do better.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Still perverse!
I say again, I will not cross my lord;
Yet I'll prevent you too. − Paper and ink, there!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Sir, 'tis ready here. (goes up to a table)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I thank you, I can write then to my chaplain.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: Sir, sir,
You may, if you please, leave out the name of my lord,
In respect he would be private, and only write,−
Marry her to this gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Well advised.
Tis done.−Away! − (gives Allworth the paper−she kneels) My blessing? Girl, thou hast it:
Nay, no reply.−Begone,good Master Allworth,
This shall be the best night's work you ever made.

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: I hope so, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Now all's cock-sure:
Methinks I hear already knights and ladies
Say, Sir Giles Overreach, how is it with
Your honourable daughter?−
My ends, my ends are compassed! − Then, for Wellborn
And the lands; were he once married to the widow −
I have him here. (touching his forehead with his finger)I can scarce contain myself,
I am so full of joy; nay, joy all over.

div.note: [If played in Three Acts, the Second ends here.]

div.head: Scene First .−The Hall in Lady Allworth's House−table and four chairs .−screen R.
div.stage: Lovell, L., and Lady Allworth, R, seated at table>

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: By this you know how strong the motives were
That did, my lord, induce me to dispense
A little, with my gravity, to advance,
The plots and projects of the down-trod Wellborn.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: What you intended, madam,
For the poor gentleman hath found good success;
For, as I understand, his debts are paid,
And he once more furnish'd for fair employment:
But all the arts that I have us'd, to raise
The fortunes of your joy and mine, young Allworth,
Stand yet in supposition, though I hope well:
For the young lovers are in wit more pregnant
Than their years can promise.(both rise)

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Though my wishes
Are with yours, my lord; yet give me leave to fear
The building, though well grounded. To deceive
Sir Giles, that's both a lion and a fox
In his proceedings, were a work beyond
The strongest undertakers; not the trial
Of two weak innocents.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Despair not, madam:
Hard things are compassed oft by easy means.
The cunning statesman, that believes he fathoms
The counsels of all kingdoms on the earth,
Is by simplicity oft over-reached.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: May he be so!−
The young ones have my warmest wishes with them.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: O, gentle lady, prove as kind to me !
You've deigned to hear, now grant my honest suit;
And if you may be won to make me happy,
But join your lips to mine, and that shall be
A solemn contract.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I were blind to my own good,
Should I refuse it; yet, my lord, receive me
As such a one, the study of whose whole life
Shall know no other object but to please you.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: If I return not, with all tenderness,
Equal respect to you, may I die wretched!

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: There needs no protestatiön, my lord,
To her that cannot doubt. −
You're welcome, sir:
Now you look like yourself.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: And will continue
Such, in my free acknowledgment that I am
Your creature, madam−and will never hold
My life mine own, when you please to command it.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: It is a thankfulness that well becomes you.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: For me, I am happy
That my endeavours prosper'd.−Saw you of late
Sir Giles, your uncle?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I heard of him, madam,
By his minister, Marrall; he's grown into strange passions
About his daughter: this last night, he look'd for
Your lordship at his home; but, missing you,
And Margaret not appearing, he is coming
To seek hjer here at Lady Allworth's house.
His wise head is much perplex'd and troubled.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I hope my project took.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: I strongly hope it.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: (without L.)Ha! find my daughter, booby, thou huge lump of nothing,
I'll bore thine eyes out else.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: May it please your lordship,
For some ends of mine own, but to withdraw
A little out of sight, though not of hearing,
You may, perhaps, have sport.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: You shall direct me. Exit Lovel, R. 2 E.

sp.speaker: Sir Giles
sp.l: Idiot! booby! booby!

sp.speaker: Marrall
sp.l: O, O, O!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I shall sol fa you, rogue!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir, for what cause
Do you use me thus?

div.stage: Enter Sir Giles, L., with distracted looks, driving in Marrall before him over to R.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Cause, slave? why, I am angry.
And thou a subject only fit for beating,
And so to cool my choler. Look to the writing;
Let but the seal be broke upon the box
That has slept in my cabinet these three years,
I'll rack thy soul for't.

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: (R., aside)]I may yet cry quittance:
Though now I suffer, and dare not resist.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Lady, by your leave, did you see my daughter, lady?
And the lord her husband? Are they in your house?
If they are, discover, that I may bid 'em joy;
And, as an entrance to her place of honour,
See you, on her left hand, bending down low,
When she nods on you; which you must receive
As a special favour.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: When I know, Sir Giles,
Her state requires such ceremony, I shall pay it;
But, in the meantime, as I am myself,
I give you to understand, I neither know
Nor care where her honour is.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: When you once see her
Led and supported by the lord her husband,
You'll be taught better.(crosses to Well.) Nephew−

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Well?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: No more!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Tis all I owe you.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Have your redeemed rags
Made you thus insolent?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Insolent to you!
Why, what are you, sir, pray, unless in years,
More than myself?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: His fortune swells him:−
aside'Tis rank−he's married. (crossing to L.)
Sir, in calm language, though I seldom use it,
I am familiar with the cause that makes you
Bear up thus bravely; there's a certain buzz
Of a stolen marriage,−do you hear?−of a stolen marriage,
In which, 'tis said, there's somebody hath been cozen'd;
I name no parties.

div.stage: (Lady Allworth turns away up stage, R.)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Well, sir, and what follows?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Marry, this; since you are peremptory. Remember,
Upon mere hope of your great match, I lent you
Some certain monies; put me in good security,
And suddenly, by mortgage or by statute,
Of some of your new possessions, or I'll have you
Dragged in your lavender robes to the gaol: you know me,
And therefore do not trifle.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Can you be
So cruel to your nephew, "now he's in
The way to rise?" was this the courtesy
You did me "in pure love, and no ends else?"

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: End me no ends! Engage the whole estate,
And force your spouse to sign it, you shall have
Three or four thousand more, to roar and swagger,
And revel in drunken taverns.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: And beg after−
Mean you not so?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: My thoughts are mine, and free.
Shall I have security?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: No, indeed you shall not:
Nor bond, nor bill, nor bare acknowledgment;
Your great looks fright not me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: But my deeds shall.−(they both draw)

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Help, murder! murder!

div.stage: Enter Amble, Watchall, Order, and two Servants with drawn swords, R., who interpose, C.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Outbrav'd!

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Let him come on,
Arm'd with his cut-throat practices to guard him;
With all his wrongs and injuries about him,
The right that I bring with me will defend me,
And punish his extortion.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: That I had thee
But single in the field!

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: You may; but make not
My house your quarrelling scene.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Were't in a church,
By heaven and hell, I'll do't!

div.stage: (Lady Allworth turns away)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: (R., to Wellborn)] Now put him to
The shewing of the deed.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: This rage is vain, sir;
For fighting, fear not, you shall have your hands full,
Upon the least incitement;−and−whereas
You charge me with a debt of monies to you−
If there be law, howe'er you have no conscience,
Either restore my land, or I'll recover
A debt, that's truly due to me from you,
In value ten times more than what you challenge.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I in thy debt! O impudence! did I not purchase
The land left by thy father, that rich land?
That had continued in Wellborn's name,
sp.stage: Enter two of Sir Giles's Servants with a box, L.
sp.l: Twenty descents, which, like a riotous fool,
Thou didst make sale of?−O, you're come at last - (to Servants)
Is not here, inclosed,
The deed that does confirm it mine?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Now, now,−

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I do acknowledge none; I ne'er passed o'er
Any such land: I grant, for a year or two
You had it in trust; which if you do discharge,
Surrendering the possession, you shall ease
Yourself and me of chargeable suits in law;
Which, if you prove not honest, as I doubt it,
Must of necessity follow.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: In my judgment,
He does advise you well.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Good! good! Conspire
With your new husband, lady; second him
In his dishonest practices; but when
This manor is extended to my use,
You'll speak in an humbler key, and sue for favour.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Never: do not hope it.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Let despair first seize me.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Yet, to shut up thy mouth, and make thee give
Thyself the lie, the loud lie, I draw out
The precious evidence; if thou canst forswear
Thy hand and seal, and make a forfeit of
Thy ears to the pillory−
sp.stage: (two Servants place the box on the table, L., Sir Giles unlocks it, and takes out the deed)
sp.l: See!−here's that will make
My interest clear − Ha!
sp.stage: (is thunderstruck at seeing the parchment blank)

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: A fair skin of parchment! (retreats to R.C.)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: Indented, I confess, and labels too;
But neither wax nor words.−How! thunder-struck!
Is this your precious evidence? this, that makes
Your interest clear!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: I am overwhelm'd with wonder!
What prodigy is this? what subtle devil
Hath razed out the inscription? the wax
Turned into dust! −
Do you deal with witches, rascal?
There is a statute for you, which will bring
Your neck in an hempen circle; yes, there is;
And now 'tis better thought for, cheater, know
This juggling shall not save you.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: To save thee,
Would beggar the stock of mercy.
sp.stage: (retires with Lady Allworth up the stage)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Marrall−Marrall−(beckoning gently)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Sir?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Though the witnesses are dead, your testimony
Help'd with an oath or two; and for thy master,
Thy liberal master, my good honest servant,
I know thou wilt swear anything, to dash
This cunning sleight; The deed being drawn too
By thee, my careful Marrall, and deliver'd
When thou wast present, will make good my title :−
Wilt thou not swear this?

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I!−No, I assure you:
I have a conscience, not sear'd like yours;
I know no deeds.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Wilt thou betray me? (drawing his sword)

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Keep him (Wellborn and Servants interpose, R.C.)
From using of his hands, I'll use my tongue
To his no little torment.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Mine own varlet
Rebel against me!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: Yes, and uncase you too:
The idiot, the patch, the slave, the booby,
Your drudge, can now anatomise you, and lay open
All your black plots, and level with the earth
Your hill of pride; and shake,
Nay pulverize, the walls you think defend you.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: O that I had thee in my gripe, I'd tear thee
Joint after joint!

sp.speaker: Mar.
sp.l: I know you are a tearer,
But I'll have first your fangs par'd off, and then
Come nearer to you;−(Sir Giles retreats in despair) when I have discover'd,
And made it good before the judge, what ways,
And devilish practices, you us'd to cozen with

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: All will come out. (to Lady A.)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: But that I will live, rogue, to torture thee,
And make thee wish, and kneel in vain, to die,
These swords that keep thee from me, should fix here,
Although they made my body but one wound,
But I would reach thee. I play the fool,
And make my anger but ridiculous:
There will be a time and place, there will be, coward,
(to Well.)When you shall feel what I dare do.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: I think so:
You dare do any ill; yet want true valour
To be honest, and repent.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: They're words I know not.
Nor e'er will learn. Patience, the beggar's virtue,
Shall find no harbour here:

div.stage: Enter two of Sir Giles's Servants, L. and go up a little.

sp.speaker: Lady A.
sp.l: Whom have we here?

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: After these storms
At length a calm appears.−My chaplain comes.−
sp.stage: Enter Parson Willdo, L. with a letter in his hand.
sp.l: Welcome, most welcome!
There's comfort in thy looks; is the deed done?
Is my daughter married? say but so, my chaplain,
And I am tame.

sp.speaker: Willdo.
sp.l: Married? Yes, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Then vanish all sad thoughts!
My doubts and fears are in the titles drowned
Of my honourable, my right honourable daughter.
Now you that plot against me,
And hoped to trip my heels up, that contemned me,
Think on't and tremble: −
sp.stage: Enter Lovel behind, R.U.E.−music behind, L.
sp.l: They come!−I hear the music.−
A lane there for my lord;−

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: This sudden heat
May yet be cooled, sir.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Make way there for my lady and my lord.

div.stage: Enter two Servants, Margaret, and Allworth, L.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: Sir, first your pardon, then your blessing, with
Your full allowance of the choice I've made.−
Not to dwell
Too long on words−this is my husband.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: How!

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: So, I assure you; all the rites of marriage,
With every circumstance, are past;
And, for right honourable son-in-law, you may say,
Your dutiful daughter.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: −Devil!−
Are they married?

sp.speaker: Willdo.
sp.l: Do a father's part, and say, Heaven give 'em joy!

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Confusion and ruin! Speak, and speak quickly,
Or thou art dead. (seizes Willdo)

sp.speaker: Willdo.
sp.l: They're married.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Thou hadst better
Have made a contract with the king of fiends,
Than these: − my brain turns!

sp.speaker: Willdo.
sp.l: Why this rage to me?
Is not this your letter, sir, and these the words−
"Marry her to this gentleman."

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: It cannot:
Nor will I e'er believe it, 'sdeath! I will not;
That I, who never left a print
Where I have trod, for the most curious search
To trace my footsteps, should be gulled by children!
Baffled and fooled, and all my hopes and labours
Defeated and made void. (crosses to L.)

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: As it appears,
You are so, my grave uncle. (Willdo retires, L.)

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Village nurses
Revenge their wrongs with curses; I'll not waste
A syllable; but thus I take the life
Which, wretched, I gave to thee.(advancing to kill Margaret. Allworth and Margaret retreat to R.)

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Hold, for your own sake!
Though charity to your daughter have quite left you,
Will you do an act, though in your hopes lost here,
Can leave no hope for peace or rest hereafter?
Consider; at the best, you're but a man;
And cannot so create your aims, but that
They may be cross'd.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Lord! thus I spit at thee,
And at thy counsel; and again desire thee,
And as thou art a soldier−if thy valour
Dares shew itself where multitude and example
Lead not the way, let's quit the house, and change
Six words in private.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: I am ready.

sp.speaker: L. All.
sp.l: Stay, sir,
Contest with one distracted?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You'll grow like him,
Should you answer his vain challenge.

sp.speaker: Sir G.
sp.l: Are you pale?
Borrow their helps; though Hercules call it odds,
I'll stand 'gainst all, as I am, hemm'd in thus –
Say, there were a squadron
Of pikes, lin'd through with shot, when I am mounted
Upon my injuries, shall I fear to charge 'em?
No: I'll through the battalia, and, that routed,
I'll fall to execution. (crosses to centre, attempts to draw his sword) Ha! I'm feeble:
Some undone widow sits upon mine arm,
And takes away the use of't; and my sword,
Glued to my scabbard with wrong'd orphans' tears,
Will not be drawn.−
Ha! what are these? (staggers back towards L.)sure, hangmen,
That come to bind my hands, and then to drag me
Before the judgment-seat.−Now they are new shapes,
And do appear like Furies, with steel whips
To scourge my ulcerous soul. Shall I then fall
Ingloriously, and yield?−No; spite of Fate,
I will be forced to hell, like to myself.
Though you were legions of accursèd spirits,
Thus would I fly among you.

div.stage: (he rushes madly towards his daughter, and falls exhausted on the stage, L.C., two Servants raise him up−he somewhat recovers, looks wildly round, then fixing his eyes with horrible reproach upon his daughter, drops his head upon his bosom, and is borne off by the two Servants, L.)

sp.speaker: Marr.
sp.l: Was it not a rare trick,
An't please your worship, to make the deed nothing?

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: What arts didst use to raze out the conveyance?

sp.speaker: Marr
sp.l: Certain minerals,
Incorporated in the ink and wax.
Besides he gave me nothing; but still fed me
With hopes and blows. If it please your worship
To call to memory, this mad beast once caused me
To urge you, or to hang, or drown yourself:
I'll do the like to him, if you command me.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: You are a rascal; and he that dares be false
To a master, though unjust, will very hardly
Be true to any other. Begone, and look not for
Reward or favour from me, till thou'st learned
To mend thy wicked life. Exit Marrall, R.

sp.speaker: Marg.
sp.l: O my poor father!

sp.speaker: Allw.
sp.l: Nay, weep not dearest.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Pray you take comfort;−
You shall be his guardians
In his distractions: − and for your land, Wellborn,
I'll be an umpire
Between you, and this, the undoubted heir
Of Sir Giles Overreach:−for me, here's the anchor
That I must fix on. (to Lady Allworth)

sp.speaker: All.
sp.l: What you shall determine,
My lord, we shall allow of.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: 'Tis the language
That I speak too; but there is something else
Beside the repossession of my land,
And payment of my debts, that I must practise.
I had a reputation, but 'twas lost
In my loose course; and until I redeem it
Some noble way, I am but half made up.
It is a time of action; if your lordship
Will please to confer a company upon me
In your command, I doubt not in my service
To my king and country but I shall do something
That may make me right again.

sp.speaker: Lov.
sp.l: Your suit is granted,
And you lov'd for the motion.

sp.speaker: Well.
sp.l: (to the audience) Nothing then
Now wants but your allowance − and in that
Our all is comprehended; which if you
Grant willingly, as a fair favour due
To the poet's and our labours, as you may;
For we despair not, gentles, of the play,
You may expect, the grace you show to-night,
Will teach us how to act, our poets how to write.

list.item: COSTUMES—Period of King James the First. Sir Giles.—Puce-coloured velvet doublet, trunks, belt, and cloak, with orange silk puffs; the dress trimmed with orange- coloured silk lace and gilt buttons; puce silk hose, the same colour as the dress, with gold embroidered clocks ; square-toed drab shoes with orange satin rosettes over them; a broad Brussels lace vandyke collar with two tassels; a round-crown brown hat, with doathers of the same colour.

Lord Lovell.—A scarlet cloth doublet, trunks, belt, and mantle, trimmed with orange silk lace, and yellow plated buttons— russet boots with red tops—black velvet hat and blue silk band, with feathers—a ruff, buff gloves with high tops, and white stocking pantaloons.

Wellborn —A brown ragged jerkin and breeches—a pair of blue hose—russet boots, and a black hat. 2nd dress.—A blue and silver doublet and trunks, plated buttons—a buff hat, and white feathers—a ruff—russet boots—buff gloves, with high tops.

Allworth.—A light mixture kerseymere doublet and trunks, trimmed with pink galloon—white silk pantaloons—russet boots with scarlet tops—hat with white feathers—lace ruff, and buff gloves with high tops.
Marrall.—Black old English dreas, black shoes, black hose, black hat, and cock’s-tail feather.

Justice Greedy.—A black kerseymere doublet, puffed with crimson silk—trunks and cloak ‘trimmed with crimson satin, and black glass buttons—white square-toed shoes—gloves with high tops, and a vandyke—black sugar-loaf hat with crimson band—black hose with embroidered clocks.

Lady Allworth.—A green velvet train dress, bordered with white satin and gold, and point lace—long sleeves, slashed and trimmed to correspond—high ruff—stomacher of point—black velvet hat, white feathers, and tassels. 2nd dress.—White satin train dress, with long sleeves, richly embroidered with gold—robe of white and gold—high ruff—jewel stomacher and cross—white satin hat and feathers.
Margaret.— White satin embroidered dress—a ruff.
